transcripts.text: Things got broken and people got hurt.
Is that possible that you would come to believe that they were more violent than maybe they are?
You don't see the number of people.  Three to five hundred people in front of you.  And it's you.
If you had engaged protesters differently, do you think there would have been a different outcome?
We are overtly conservative Republicans and very, very rare in this neighborhood.
Are you saying that you think the protesters were coming towards your house or they were coming towards the neighborhood?
We would not be here alive.  Our house would not be here.

Hey, family, it's Carlos Watson.  I've got a very important and a very special episode today.  Remember the white couple that was brandishing guns in front of their home last summer, right during the Black Lives Matter protests, Mark and Patty McCloskey?  Well, they're stopping by to talk with me.  It was a wide-ranging conversation.  They were generous with their time.  They gave me over an hour.  Really interesting insights.  If I'm 100% honest, there are parts that were tough to hear, but I think it's an important conversation, and it's part of what we always promise you, which is we're going to introduce you to a wide range of perspectives.  Enjoy.  Let me know what you think.  Mark, Patricia.
Hi, how are you doing?
Good.  Are you guys in St.  Louis, or where are you guys today?
We're in St.  Louis.  We're at the scene of the crime.
Okay, okay.  And have you guys moved at all during COVID, or have you literally been at home kind of March all the way through now?

We've been home the whole time.  I mean, our office is very small.  It's just two of us and one staff member typically.  And so being essential workers and all, I mean, truth and justice never sleeps, as they say.
So we go to the office every day.
Oh, you literally go to your office?
Oh, yeah.  It's a mile away.
No, it's a half a mile away.

Very nice.  Now, are you guys walkers?  or are you guys, you know, they have that funny scene, that movie with Steve Martin back in the day where he lives in L.A.  and he drives down the block, one block.  So do you guys walk?  Do you guys?
It's three blocks away, but we drive.
Okay, okay.  I love that.  So you have a little Steve Martin in you.  That's not bad.  That's good.  That's good.  How did you guys end up in St.  Louis?
I was born and raised here, and we decided to come back here, and it was a good place to do what we did for a living in those days.

Holding a high-powered rifle and wielding a pistol, in these now viral images, Mark and Patricia McCloskey looked ready for a gunfight as a protest moved through their mansion-lined St.  Louis neighborhood.  Despite the tense armed encounter, it appears no Missouri laws were broken, and the couple is insisting they do not oppose the Black Lives Matter movement and were simply trying to protect their families.

I know you guys have had so many different conversations over the last, what is it now, probably seven or eight months since that evening.  How do you guys think back about that night as you stand here today in January?

The interesting thing to us is that We had the first night, June the 28th, and we get to report it on the media.  And that was the easier of the two events.  The mob came back on July the 3rd with the express intent of killing us and burning down the House.  And now this mob was estimated at between 500 and 1,000.  That was the carry night.  That was the time when we really thought the end had come.  And our new congresswoman, the lady that represents us in the House of Representatives now, was standing outside the fence with a megaphone chanting, you can't stop the revolution.  Well, the Navy SEAL, who is my personal protection, standing behind me, leaning on his M-16, said, oh, yes, I can.  It was a harrowing night.
This is our new representative, Cori Bush.

When you describe her saying you can't stop the revolution, that doesn't immediately mean violence to me.  And I guess that's the question I'm asking you, whether you are reading into what she is saying with more violent references than maybe are frankly intended.  Is that possible that you were more charged and more loaded in the moment and you weren't as much at risk, except that you had come to believe that they were more violent than maybe they are?

Yeah, that's a fair question.  And in a vacuum, I could see how they could say that.  The problem is that they have protested a lot.  prior to our event.  And every time they did, things got broken and people got hurt.  There were none of these protests where they were benign events.  If half of them were benign events and I had to judge, gee, is this going to be one of those 50% times when nothing gets broken and nobody gets hurt?  I'd still probably be out there because a 50-50 chance of getting killed is too much.  So they can say in a vacuum, maybe they would have just walked on by.  But when they did finally walk on by... They did engage in violence and try to burn the mayor's house.  They've done it before and they've done it since.  Right now in this room we're sitting in, we've got Lexan on the windows to prevent firebombs from coming in.  And so it's not unreasonable under the circumstance.
You could hear a reasonable person saying there were lots of protests in a variety of places and that had you not brandished guns, it wouldn't have amped things up.  How do you, is that reasonable?

The proof of that putting is in what they did say.  After we discouraged them from engaging in violence in our house, they went down to the mayor's house and engaged in violence and tried to burn our house down.  And so my instincts were not charged by race and not charged by any kind of white privilege type background.  What it was based on was their prior behaviors.  the same group in the same city in the same month.  And now, in retrospect, by what they did at the mayor's house, not just this one night, but many nights afterwards, they came back to the mayor's house and tried to burn it down.

If you had to do all of this over again, would you have done anything differently?  And I'm not asking that critically, but I'm asking, you know, with the benefit of hindsight and as I hear you guys think about this and wrestle with this, would you have done anything differently that first night, do you think?
I wish, because I beat myself up, I think what could I have done?  Nothing.  We would not be here alive.  Our house would not be here.
I mean, these folks.

You don't understand the things that they were yelling.  I mean, these people were.  And you don't play it, and they don't show it, and you don't see the number of people.  Three to 500 people in front of you.
And it's you.
And Mark was on the side porch.  I realized after I called 911, I saw Mark said private property.  As soon as he said private property, that upset them.

Mark, do you think if you would come out without weapons and if instead of saying private property, you would engage the protesters differently, do you think there would have been a different outcome?  And again, I'm not asking this critically, but I'm just taking a step back with the benefit of hindsight.  You know, do you think what you think things would have worked out differently?

Would I make a different decision?  Would it de-escalate?  I don't know.  But I think it's just as likely that I would not be here today and this house would still be a smoldering ruin if we hadn't taken the action we had.
And how do you de-escalate among 300 screaming, irate people?  It's just more noise, more calamity than you could ever embrace.

Am I supposed to interview each person as they breach that gate and say, are you the good protester or are you the violent mobster?  Are you a person who just wants to make some noise to get on TV?  Or are you one of those people that shot police officers and burned 7-Elevens and killed David Dorn?  This was not a crowd which you could trust to be harmless.  And every indication was that they had no intention of being armed.
Are you saying that you think they were coming originally, the protesters were coming towards your house, or they were coming towards the neighborhood?

I don't know if it was specifically us or the neighborhood.  We live in a very liberal neighborhood.  We are overtly conservative Republicans and very, very rare in this neighborhood.  And so the fact that they came in the gate on our side instead of the gate on the other side, it's unknowable unless you ask Cori Bush because she was there and she was in charge of the organization.  But, you know, no one stole us one way or the other.

Patty, when you think about President Trump, do you think that he has inflamed race relations over the last four years?  Do you feel like he's been a help as it relates to that, a hurt, somewhere in between?  How do you think about the job he's done?

Well, I think he's helped a lot.  I think he's reached out to people.  He's released people from prison.  He has had all sorts of other voices in the White House to open up his ideas, his thinking about racism.  why the people that are in jail are in jail.  Maybe this was over, that maybe we should start letting these people out.  I think that that's really open-minded of him.
No, no, I meant on race relations, not on prison reform, but on race relations.  Do you think on race relations he's been a good president?

Yeah, I believe so, because I thought... Unemployment is lower for African-Americans.  And I say race relations in prison because when I see the mainstream news, they're putting those things together.

Mark, how do you think about the president?  Because you know that even members of his own party have spent a lot of time talking to various Republican senators, members of the House.  Even people who supported the president have often said to me, Candidly, Carlos, I don't like the way he's handled matters of race.  I think he's made things worse.  I think he's supported white supremacists with the folks in Charlottesville, the things he said when he was announcing his campaign, the birtherism.  You think the president has done a good job on race?

I think the president has done a good job on race.  I think the press from the day he came down the escalator has tried to make race an issue to take voters away from him.  Every single speech that I've heard him say, he has been as inclusive as humanly possible.  part of what he says gets reported, just like 32 seconds of our event gets reported.  And it becomes the truth.  There's no longer empirical truth out there.  It's the accepted narrative that becomes the truth.  And the accepted narrative is generated by the media.

So when you think about media that you admire and you think about media that in your mind is doing a quality job, who's at the top of that list?  Who are some of the media outlets that you think are actually distinguishing themselves?

Always Tucker.  Maria Bartiromo is a solid person.  Sean Hannity is a solid.  And Laura Ingraham.  And we look at Newsmax, and Newsmax is pretty solid because some of the figures at Fox are starting to fail.
But I mean, on the other side, one of the first shows that had me on was Chris Cuomo.  And before he knew anything about the facts, he was already calling me the face of white supremacy.
Mark, just to pause you a moment, because I did watch that clip.  I thought he said white resistance.  I didn't think he said white supremacy.  But do you remember it differently than I do?
Well, if you've watched it more recently, I haven't.  I haven't seen it in six months.
How do you feel about becoming the face of political resistance to the Black Lives Matter movement?
I'm not sure that there is a functional difference between those terms.  I would be just as offended by white resistance.

Interesting.  But, you know, it's so interesting that you say that, Mark.  And I actually think that that's really powerful and intriguing because I do think that there's a meaningful difference between white resistance and white supremacy.  But I think it's one of those issues about how we receive the same information.  Is it possible that sometimes we can both look at something and someone can see risk?  and violence and certainty that they're at risk, and someone else can just see protesters exercising their First Amendment, trying to push us towards a better place on questions of race and social justice.  I wonder if that's deeper and more real than maybe we always appreciate.

Well, you know, on the concept of white resistance versus white supremacy, neither one is a compliment.  OK, both of them are charged with an accusation of racism.  Both of them would be just as deeply offensive to me.  They may be different points on the curve, but they're both on the side of the curve that goes towards racism.  And they're both an insult.  They're both an accusation of frame of mind that I do not possess.  It's not that I'm saying those are equal terms, but they are equally offensive to me because they're equally a reference to racism that I did not appreciate.

Mark, point taken, and I appreciate you saying that, and point taken.  We all know that this is a closely divided country, that there is a lot of animus and agita for a variety of reasons.  And I've often said to people, what would happen if we all got together and tried to think about resetting America?  Not about only the last 250 years, but also about the next 250.  What would be one or two of the ideas that you'd want to put on the table in order to make sure that our next chapter is a good one?

I think that all this talk about potentially critical race theory now is driving a further wedge between people that never thought that they should treat people differently because of race are now being actively told that if they don't treat people differently because of their race, they are racist.  It seems totally upside down to me.

Let me explore that maybe a little bit more, even as we talk about this a little bit here, too.  Often you have heard that there's not a level playing field and that things aren't in the same place for people of different races on average.  You say what to that?

I wish I could.  have a way of creating an environment where people can all just work together and do so in an environment where everybody was considered equal under the law, equal opportunity, equal rights, equal respect, so we could move forward without having to compartmentalize people based on all these different things.

Mark and Patty, if you don't mind, I'd love to close by doing what I call rapid fire, asking you a couple of quick questions and getting your immediate responses.  I'd love to know from each of you, who's your favorite comedian?
My favorite comedian was Red Skelton.
Oh, my goodness.  You really did go back.  All right.  Favorite book?
I was going to say the exact same thing.  1984.
What's your karaoke song?
If you've heard either one of us sing, you would not ask that question.
Never karaoke, but how about?  I'm Still Standing?
I like that.  That's a good one.  If you guys could have dinner with anyone, dead or alive, who would you love to have a meal with?
For me, Kurt Vonnegut.
Katherine Hepburn.
Patty, Mark, I just want to thank you guys again.  I so appreciate you guys taking out the time to have this conversation.  And I wish you a very healthy and a very good 2021.
Thank you very much for having us on your show.
You're a very kind and thoughtful interviewer.  I do appreciate that.  And you listen and I will start listening to you because you're very worth listening to.
And now I have an answer to your question about who in the media I would defer to.  And now we've got one.
You know, I'm honored, and I'm going to try and make sure I live up to that.  Thank you guys for taking the time.
Thank you.  Thank you again for having us.

Hey, I hope you enjoyed that conversation.  I know for a lot of people that was probably a tough conversation to watch.  For other people, enlightening, maybe even surprising.  It's part of what we want to do on the show.  I think that, particularly as I think about matters of race, racial reconciliation, racial progress, I think it's going to be important to hear from a variety of people.  If I'm 100% honest, I can't say that I agree with a lot of what the McCloskeys shared.  I do wonder whether there's a different way for them to see the world and be in the world.  But I appreciated them being here.  I appreciated them sharing what they thought.  Hope you'll continue to enjoy this show.  If you do, remember you can subscribe.  You also can listen to the podcast.  It's often got an extended version of the conversation.  And if you're finding something valuable here, think about telling your friends.  Thanks for joining me.  I'll see you soon.
